Introduction

Viruses are obligate intracellular agents that lack metabolic activity and rely on host cells for energy requirements and macromolecule synthesis.  A complete virus particle (virion) consists of a nucleic acid genome (RNA or DNA) enclosed in a viral-encoded protein capsid; some virions have a (host-derived) lipid-bilayer envelope studded with viral glycoproteins.  Viruses infect all forms of life and are responsible for a vast array of human illnesses.  They are classified based on size, shape (eg, helical/icosahedral), chemical composition and structure of the genome (eg, single stranded [ss] or double stranded [ds], linear/circular, monopartite/multipartite), and mode of replication.

Viral structure



Virions deliver nucleic acid to a host cell to be translated by host machinery.  Outside of the host cell, they are inert.  The main structural elements of a virion are discussed next.

Capsid



Capsids are composed of viral-encoded, identical protein subunits called protomers, which self-assemble into a regular, well-defined array that surrounds and protects the viral nucleic acid from environmental damage.  They also assist with host cell binding and entry (in nonenveloped viruses).  There are 3 main types of capsids (

figure 1
):



  • Icosahedral:  Protomers form oligomeric clusters (capsomeres) that self-assemble into polyhedral or spherical forms with 20 equilateral triangular faces.  Icosahedral nucleocapsids are seen in many RNA (eg, poliovirus) and DNA (eg, adenovirus, herpesvirus) viruses.
  • Helical:  Protomers form a helix of rods or flexible filaments around a very tight coil of nucleic acid.  Helical nucleocapsids are often seen with ssRNA viruses (eg, rabies, influenza, Ebola) and frequently require an envelope to increase structural stability.
  • Complex:  Protomers form complex shapes that may be irregular or may have both helical and icosahedral elements (eg, a bacteriophage with an icosahedral head and helical tail).  Complex nucleocapsids are most common in viruses with large genomes (eg, poxviruses, reoviruses).

Envelope



Some viruses have an envelope that surrounds the capsule.  Envelopes are a lipid bilayer derived from the host cell membrane during viral budding (most common), cell lysis, or exocytosis.  Envelopes are spiked with viral glycoproteins, which assist with host cell attachment and entry.  Differences between enveloped and nonenveloped viruses follow (

figure 2
):



  • Enveloped viruses:

    • More sensitive to environmental factors (eg, heat, desiccation, detergents) due to the fragile lipid bilayer; therefore, direct host-to-host contact (eg, respiratory droplets, bodily fluids) is typically required for transmission.
    • Better able to evade immune detection and facilitate membrane fusion due to the presence of a host-derived lipid bilayer.
    • Typically released from host cells by budding.
    • Examples:  Influenza virus, HIV, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), herpesviruses.
  • Nonenveloped (naked) viruses:
    • More resistant to harsh environmental conditions, allowing for diverse transmission routes (eg, fecal-oral, fomite, aerosol, water).
    • Typically released from host cells by lysis.
    • Examples:  Adenoviruses, picornaviruses (eg, poliovirus), norovirus.

Genome



Viruses have either an RNA or a DNA genome that can be organized in a variety of ways (eg, ss/ds, linear/circular, monopartite/multipartite).  The chemical composition of the genome determines the replication mechanism and classification.

RNA viruses



Approximately 70% of all viruses have an RNA genome.  Most RNA viruses (excluding retroviruses) replicate their genome in the cytoplasm using RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.  Because this enzyme has a high error rate compared to DNA polymerase, RNA viruses tend to accumulate mutations (variants) more rapidly than DNA viruses and to be more adaptable to changing host conditions.  RNA viruses are classified as follows (

figure 3
):



  • ssRNA viruses:

    • Positive-sense (+) ssRNA viruses have genomes that can serve as mRNA; they are translated by host ribosomes in their entirety (as a viral polyprotein) and subsequently cleaved into individual viral proteins.  The virus encodes for an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is synthesized after infection and generates a negative-sense RNA intermediate that acts as a template for a positive-sense copy of the genome.  Examples include coronaviruses (eg, SARS-CoV-2), flaviviruses (eg, dengue virus, hepatitis C virus [HCV]), and picornaviruses (eg, poliovirus, rhinovirus, hepatitis A virus [HAV]).  Retroviruses, which are also positive-sense ssRNA viruses, replicate via a DNA intermediate (as discussed later).
    • Negative-sense (−) ssRNA viruses have genomes that cannot be directly translated by host ribosomes.  Therefore, the virion must carry a preformed RNA-dependent RNA polymerase enzyme to convert the negative-sense RNA into a complementary positive-sense RNA strand.  The host ribosome then translates the positive-sense strand into viral proteins; the strand also serves as a template for new copies of negative-sense RNA as part of replication.  All known negative-sense ssRNA viruses are enveloped.  Examples include influenza, rabies, and measles viruses.
  • dsRNA viruses:
    • Because dsRNA cannot function as directly as mRNA, a preformed RNA-dependent RNA polymerase is packaged in the virion.  This enzyme transcribes the negative-sense strand into positive-sense mRNA, which is then translated by host ribosomes into viral proteins.  The positive-sense RNA also serves as a template for viral replication.  The most common example is rotavirus.
  • Retroviruses (
    figure 4
    ):
    • Retrovirus genomes are composed of 2 identical positive-sense ssRNA molecules; however, these are not used as mRNA.  Instead, the virus brings a reverse transcriptase enzyme, which converts the viral RNA genome into DNA.  The viral DNA then integrates into the host genome (provirus) and is subsequently transcribed by host RNA polymerase II; this generates positive-sense RNA that serves as mRNA and as a template for replication of the genome.  Examples include HIV and human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV).

DNA viruses



The genome of most DNA viruses is monopartite (contained in a single nucleic acid molecule), linear, and composed of dsDNA.  However, some viral species have an ssDNA genome (eg, parvovirus) or a circular double-stranded DNA genome (eg, papillomavirus).  DNA viruses use viral or host DNA polymerase to replicate, most often in the nucleus (

figure 5
).  A broad categorization of DNA viruses is provided in this figure (
figure 6
).

Viral life cycle



Viral infection requires attachment to a host cell, penetration of the cell surface, and uncoating to make the genome accessible for translation and replication.  The viral life cycle is typically characterized by these steps.

Attachment



The surface of the virion has viral-encoded attachment proteins that bind to specific receptors (usually large glycoproteins) on a host cell.  Some viruses have attachment proteins that target many cell types across a range of species, whereas others are capable of infecting only a certain type of differentiated cell in a single species (eg, human papillomavirus [HPV] can infect only human keratinocytes).  Complex viruses (eg, herpesvirus) often have more than a single type of attachment protein.  Attachment efficiency is dependent on receptor availability and temperature/electrostatic interactions.

Penetration



Penetration allows the virion (or portions of the virion) to enter the host cell.  It is an energy-dependent step, which occurs almost immediately after attachment.  Penetration typically involves one of the following mechanisms:



  • Translocation of the virion across the plasma membrane.
  • Endocytosis of the virion, leading to virion accumulation within cytoplasmic vacuoles.
  • Fusion of the virion envelope with the cell membrane.


Nonenveloped viruses are either translocated or undergo endocytosis, whereas enveloped viruses fuse with the cell membrane.

Uncoating



After the virion enters the cell, it disaggregates to release its genome for expression with or without the assistance of cellular enzymes.  For instance, the nucleocapsids of adenovirus, herpesvirus, and HPV are transported to nuclear pores; viral DNA is then released directly into the nucleus.  In contrast, viruses that undergo endocytosis (eg, influenza) often use acidification to release their genome from the nucleocapsid into the cytoplasm.

Transcription/replication



The crucial event in viral replication is the synthesis of viral proteins by host cell machinery.  However, no host cell enzyme can synthesize messenger RNA from a viral RNA genome or transcribe viral DNA in the cytoplasm.  Therefore, only viruses that deliver their DNA to the nucleus can use host machinery for transcription.  All other viruses must either deliver a positive-sense ssRNA genome to the cell (which can serve as mRNA) or carry transcription enzymes (eg, RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, reverse transcriptase) in the virion.  Host or viral polymerases are responsible for replicating the genome.

Assembly/release



Nonenveloped viruses assemble a procapsid in the nucleus or cytoplasm, package their genome, and then leave the cell via one of the following mechanisms (

figure 7
):



  • Host cell lysis (majority) causes cell death.  Virions accumulate until the cell membrane is disrupted or the virus produces enzymes that damage the host cell membrane.  Examples include adenoviruses, picornaviruses, and most parvoviruses.
  • Exocytosis is marked by the release of virions in exosomes, which does not cause cell death.  This is seen with picornaviruses (eg, HAV, poliovirus) and polyomaviruses (eg, JC virus, BK virus).
  • Cell-to-cell transmission can occur in a minority of viruses, which may cause host cell death.  This is typically marked by the fusion of adjacent cells or direct contact between an infected and an uninfected cell.


In contrast, enveloped viruses typically combine viral assembly with release from the host cell.  Enveloped viruses (eg, retroviruses; negative-sense ssRNA viruses) insert viral proteins into the host plasma membrane.  Viral nucleocapsids then attach to the cytoplasmic surface of these proteins, and the virus is extruded ("buds") into the extracellular environment.

Effect on the host cell



Viral infection can result in host cell death, persistent infection, or host cell transformation, as follows:



  • Cytocidal (cytolytic) infections cause host cell death; most viral infections are cytocidal.  Histopathology often shows rounding of the host cell, the formation of inclusion bodies in the nucleus/cytoplasm, and (in some viruses) the fusion of an infected cell with an adjacent cell to form a syncytium.
  • Persistent infections are marked by viral infection in a limited number of cells following acute infection.  Replication rate and spread are typically limited by the humoral and cell-mediated immune response.  Persistent viral infections are often categorized as follows:
    • Slow infections (eg, measles virus) are marked by a prolonged incubation period in which the infected host cell harbors the virus for months or years without developing cytopathic changes.  However, the infection eventually causes cellular injury, leading to cell death.
    • Chronic infections (eg, HCV) are characterized by continuous low-level viral replication in host cell tissues.  The virus typically causes a cytocidal reaction, but the replication cycle is slower, intermittent, or limited to a few host cells.
    • Latent infections (eg, cytomegalovirus, varicella-zoster virus, herpes simplex virus type 1 [HSV-1]) are marked by extreme restriction on viral replication and gene expression.  Host cells with latent infection typically appear normal on histopathology.
  • Transforming infections are a type of persistent infection associated with oncogenic transformation of the host cell.  DNA viruses (eg, Epstein-Barr virus, HPV) typically cause transforming infection only when viral gene expression is restricted to immediate early/early proteins because full viral replication kills the host cell.  In contrast, transforming RNA viruses (eg, HTLV) can cause oncogenesis while undergoing replication because they typically do not cause cytolysis.

Major viral diseases



Viruses cause a wide variety of human diseases across many organ systems.  Common examples of these viruses follow:



  • Respiratory:  Influenza virus, SARS-CoV-2, rhinovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza virus.
  • Gastrointestinal:  Norovirus, rotavirus, HAV, astrovirus.
  • Hepatic:  Hepatitis B virus, HCV, hepatitis E virus.
  • Neurologic:  Rabies virus, poliovirus, HSV-1 (encephalitis), arboviruses (West Nile virus, Zika virus).
  • Exanthems:  Measles virus, rubella virus, varicella-zoster virus.
  • Oncogenic:  HPV, Epstein-Barr virus, Kaposi sarcoma–associated herpesvirus.
  • Immunodeficiency:  HIV-1, HIV-2.

Summary



Viruses are obligate intracellular pathogens that have a single- or double-stranded RNA or DNA genome, a virally encoded protein capsid, and (in some viruses) an outer lipid-bilayer envelope.  Viral pathogens infect all forms of life; in humans, they cause a wide variety of diseases across most organ systems.  Viral infection can result in acute, chronic, latent, and/or transforming infection.
